article.description: Gabe York scored 20 points, Nick Johnson added 16 and No. 5 Arizona crushed Fairleigh Dickinson 100-50 to open the NIT Season Tip-Off on Monday night.
article.shortLinkText: York, Johnson help Arizona double up FDU
article.headline: Gabe York, Nick Johnson help Arizona double up FDU 100-50
article.linkText: York, Johnson help Arizona double up FDU
article.story:
TUCSON, Ariz. -- Gabe York hit 3-pointers. Rondae Hollis-Jefferson soared in for dunks. T.J. McConnell whipped passes around the court to set up easy baskets.

Even when the game got out of reach, No. 5 Arizona kept pouring it on, coming up with the kind of rout that might become commonplace for a team as deep and talented as this one.

York scored a career-high 20 points, Nick Johnson added 16 and Arizona crushed Fairleigh Dickinson 100-50 to open the NIT Season Tip-Off on Monday night.

"The way our team is this year, we have to go full throttle every step of the way," said York, who was 4-of-6 from 3-point range. "Every second of every game, we have to go 100 percent."

Arizona (4-0) needed a little bit of a kick start after allowing the Knights to keep it close early.

Once the Wildcats got rolling, there was no stopping them.

Led by Hollis-Jefferson and McConnell, Arizona reeled off runs of 18-3 and 18-2 to build a 37-point halftime lead.

The Wildcats didn't let up, either, shooting 54 percent, making 10 of 19 from 3-point range and outrebounding FDU 50-20, including 20 offensive rebounds that led to 27 second-chance points.

Arizona had 19 assists and five turnovers, and got production throughout the lineup.

Hollis-Jefferson finished with 13 points, McConnell had nine assists with one turnover, and Aaron Gordon overcame a rough shooting night to finish with 10 points and 10 rebounds.

Arizona moves on to face Rhode Island on Tuesday night with a trip to Madison Square Garden on the line.

Not a bad way for Sean Miller to become the fifth coach to win 100 games at Arizona.

"To play a game with only five turnovers is outstanding," Miller said. "We made great decisions. That's a great sign early in the year."

Fairleigh Dickinson (1-3) held its own in the opening minutes, standing up to the bigger, more athletic Wildcats and their revolving door of interchangeable players.

The Knights didn't have enough to keep up once Arizona got rolling, helpless as the Wildcats dropped in a barrage of 3-pointers, dunks and putbacks to double up the score.

Sidney Sanders Jr. had 16 points and Matt MacDonald added 11 for FDU, which will face Metro State at McKale Center on Tuesday night.

"We knew it was going to be a tough game," FDU coach Greg Herenda said. "Sean is a great coach, and Arizona shot the ball well. They don't really have a weakness, but they exploited some of our weaknesses."

Arizona followed easy opening wins over Cal Poly and Long Beach State by passing its first test of the season, winning 69-60 at San Diego State on Thursday.

The Wildcats weren't expected to face much of a challenge in the two games at the McKale Center before heading to New York for the semifinals next week.

Fairleigh Dickinson had been outscored by an average of 25 points in 11 straight losses to ranked opponents since 1996 and had lost 10 straight overall on the road after falling 74-60 at Hartford on Friday.

The Knights didn't seem intimidated by the opponent or playing in one of college basketball's most difficult road venues in the early going, though, aggressively driving to the basket and confidently pulling up for 3-pointers.

Sanders, FDU's 5-foot-11 point guard, repeatedly took his man off the dribble to get to the rim, scoring eight points in the first five minutes to keep the Knights tied at 10.

"I was proud of how our team came out after the first two TV timeouts," Herenda said. "I think we were even tied after the first one and we were competitive."

Then Hollis-Jefferson took over.

The left-hander wasn't quite as heralded as his teammate Gordon coming in, but was still one of the nation's best incoming freshmen.

Hollis-Jefferson showed off his all-around game against FDU, blocking a shot, scoring on hard drive and hustling to keep another possession alive with two rebounds. He followed with a soaring rebound slam, then put Arizona up 25-13 on a three-point play by getting an off-balance shot to fall after being hit on a drive.

Then it was McConnell's turn.

He set up York for a 3-pointer with a baseline drive-and-kick, had a steal that led to a tomahawk dunk by York and set up another basket with a no-look pass in transition.

McConnell and Hollis-Jefferson punctuated the first half together: an alley pass from the point guard to the freshman, who brought the crowd to its feet with a dunk over FDU's Mathias Seilund.

Hollis-Jefferson had 11 points, McConnell had five assists and Arizona led 51-24 after making 18 of 32 shots.

"It's great to play when you've got it going on, your teammates are pushing it for fast-break dunks, transition 3s," Hollis-Jefferson said. "All those plays are great; you want to have plays like that. It's great to see us playing like that."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
